example[0]: There was a slight chill in the air.
example[1]: I turned on the heater in the hall to take the chill off the house  (=to heat it slightly).
example[2]: Suddenly aware of the morning chill, she closed the window.
example[3]: He sat in the chill of the evening, staring out over the city below.
definition[1]: a sudden feeling of fear or worry, especially because of something cruel or violent
example[4]: The sound of his dark laugh sent a chill through her.
example[5]: There was something in his tone that sent a chill down Melissa’s spine (=made her very frightened).
example[6]: Fay felt a chill of fear as she watched Max go off with her daughter.
definition[2]: an illness which causes a slight fever, headache, and shivering (=slight shaking of the body)
example[7]: Let’s get these wet clothes off you before you catch a chill.
definition[3]: a feeling of being cold, caused by being ill
definition[4]: if you chill something such as food or drink, or if it chills, it becomes very cold but does not freeze
example[8]: Spoon the mixture into a bowl and chill for two hours.
example[9]: The longer this salad chills, the better the flavour.
definition[5]: to relax completely instead of feeling angry, tired, or nervous
example[10]: ‘Hold it! Just chill for a second, won’t you!’
example[11]: I spent the afternoon chilling out in front of the TV.
example[12]: The wind blew across her body, chilling her wet skin.
example[13]: Come and sit by the fire – you look chilled to the bone.
definition[7]: to suddenly frighten someone, especially by seeming very cruel or violent
example[14]: The anger in his face chilled her.
example[15]: He jerked his head round and saw something that chilled his blood.
note[4]: chill somebody to the bone/chill somebody to the marrow/chill somebody’s blood
